newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: Lithuania bourse shows signs of recovery.
newsitem.headline: Lithuania bourse shows signs of recovery.

text.p: Lithuania's fledging bourse showed signs of recovery on Tuesday and dealers were bullish on the market's prospects for the autumn.
Volume on the central market was over 1.3 million litas compared with 128,000 litas last Thursday.

The central market, which seldom tops 200,000 litas, was boosted by the debut of state-run oil firm Lietuvos Kuras, which saw 240,000 of its shares traded at the price of five litas for a deal worth 1.2 million litas.
Dealers were tight-lipped about the deal. Lietuos Kuras is to be merged by parliament later this month with three other state-run oil sector firms.
Market leader Vilniaus bank, which is majority owned by the huge Bankers Trust, saw its price rise five percent to 1,050 litas and 28 of its shares were traded.
Brokers said that prices on the central market were on the rise and they expected the trend to continue through the autumn.
"We expect to see prices on the central market continue to rise. A growing number of foreign investors are showing an interest in the Lithuanian market," said one dealer.
"Some investors who have succeeded on the Estonian market are now eyeing Lithuania. Estonia's market is stabilising and Lithuania is looking more profitable."

Brokers also said that local and foreign investors were beginning to turn to equities in the wake of a steep drop in T-bill rates, which have fallen to between nine and 12 percent after hitting almost 40 percent in February.
Lithuania's bourse has yet to establish an index but bourse officials say they hope to have one this autumn.
The volume on Tuesday's secondary T-bill market was 93,500 litas and the yields ranged from 10.00 percent to 13.81 percent.
